Apr 11

Stop Saying You Hate Meetings!

Not all “meetings” are created equal.

“We all hate meetings.” You don’t have to look long before you find a post that says this on Medium, and most people will just nod and agree without thinking further.

But hey, I disagree!

I don’t hate meetings (and actually, I bet you don’t either). What we hate are BAD meetings. Bleh meetings. Life-draining meetings. You know the ones where you keep drinking coffee just to make something happen only resulting in you feeling frustrated and shaking.

And yet, we all happen to love GREAT meetings. I know you do, and if you’ve never experienced a great meeting, please find a new job.

Not all “meetings” are created equal. We can’t cover all types of meetings by just calling them “meetings.” We should all know by now that putting everyone into a blanket category is not functional or fair. Doing this gives the wrong impression and creates the groundwork for wrong conclusions.

Can you remember one of those workshops where you “saw the light”? Maybe even came out of it with some feeling of adrenaline. Some, “fuck, we are taking over THE WORLD” vibes. Are those beads of sweat on your forehead?! “Where did the time go?”

In a great meeting, it all comes together. Ideas are flowing. You are in the realm of potential. It gets intense because all the right people with all the right intentions are fully present.

You are so focused on succeeding that you bring your best. You walk out of there wanting to run down the hall with a fog horn and high five everyone you see. But hey… you just met up with other people in the same room at a scheduled time.

Wait a second…was that a “MEETING”?!?

We don’t need to cut down on meetings. We need to cut down on BAD meetings.

To balance things out, we need to create more of the good meetings. Sometimes even inviting more people to more meetings is better, just to break down walls and open up the more common dialog in your company.

So to get an understanding of meeting types, let’s try to break it down and look at what we really hate and what we might actually love.

Here’s a List of Meetings I Hate/Love:

Status Meetings Won’t Get You Anywhere

Status meetings are a waste of time and should be axed. Following Jason Fried’s excellent example, we recently started using Basecamp to stay updated and aligned with each other. I skip the need for status meetings entirely by making a weekly written check-in instead.

We don’t meet to align, we meet to discuss and prioritize. Our change in approach has made a big difference.

Checking on a “status” is not the same as looking forward. Who wants to know status anyways? I want to know where we are going and how we get there.

I hate “I’ll call in and then we can make a decision” meetings

Kill me with a spoon — why can’t we just make a decision right now, right here? Try using Slack (or wherever you write with your colleagues). You just had a dialogue around this topic. You have the context right here. Make the decision already and get going.

It can take a bit of time for people to get used to making bigger decisions in writing. But you will quickly see the benefits of it. I’ll delve into this for another post, but writing and having time to think between arguments, in my experience, has resulted in better decisions.

“But it’s big decision.” Okay… but seeing your face does not excuse the fact that big decisions will inevitably be put in writing, so let’s skip the curtseys. Write it in caps-lock if it makes you feel better.

I hate meetings in the morning

The truth is, I feel more productive before lunch. I like it to be quiet so I can focus on my tasks. If I have one or more meetings before noon, I feel an unproductive wobble for the rest of the day. So people need a really good excuse to invite me to anything before lunch.

I love workshops

The best meetings are when we all get in a room to create something. We are all on the same page about the subject. We share a common goal. A workshop doesn’t need to be either long or complicated. My last one was with our Senior Designer agreeing on a new process for running the website using Invision and trying out design sprints. My next one is called “The Future of Tools & Integrations”. We will brainstorm on how to take our setup to the next level.

I love meetings talking about the future

The future gets me excited. I get so much motivation from in-person sessions about envisioning the future, and it’s just not the same when you do this in writing. You don’t get the same inspiration and level of exchange. You don’t get to feel the passion in the room. It’s not always productive I know, but it can be great for motivation, starting new projects, and exploring ideas. Envisioning the future invites your colleagues into sharing the bigger perspective.

Of course, this is not a complete list of meeting types, but the ones that have the most function (or dysfunction) in my field. I’m curious to know your personal list of “love/hate meetings.” Feel free to add them to the comments below.

A Look at My Calendar

So how do I address the need for meetings in my company? Inspired by Jason Fried once again, and his post “what my calendar looks like,” here’s a screenshot of my next week:

Team lead check-in on Monday

Team leads are “Head of Sales EU/US, Head of Marketing & Head of Support.” We start by doing 5 minutes around the table with the latest numbers, then we go through a weekly list of “things to discuss.” Yes, the “5 minutes around the table” is also made in a written format as well before the meeting. But we like saying them out loud as well.

This week, we spent the last 45 minutes on two topics: sharing learnings on hiring and discussing how we can align onboarding between our HQ and US office. Then we discussed a new pricing structure we want to roll out globally. We got everyone’s input and had it ready for sales to take from there.

All hands, Every other Monday

Our company’s All hands meeting includes everyone in the company meeting every other week. We share different topics from different people, and encourage creativity. Last time, 4 people made a presentation of the difference working at Airtame 2 years ago compared to now. Next week, I’m doing a small talk called “We are building the trigger, ” and we will officially welcome a new hire. Our format is still being tweaked, but one thing we found out is that this meeting format is a great space for motivation.

Manager meeting, Tuesday

Managers are CTO, Head of Product, CEO and me. We each create an update in writing before the meeting (using Basecamp check-ins), so we are on the same page before we get together. We use this time to discuss things. Things like how we bring our teams closer together. Should we start preparing for a Series A? Should we even do a Series A? We talk about hiring and people. We allow ourselves to go deeper into the discussion because we don’t have to spend time on updating where each of us is coming from. A lot of this is actually also starting to take place in Basecamp. So everyone shares at least their point of view on a certain topic before our meeting.

“💭”, Every other Friday

This is a new type of meeting, a one-hour “let’s see what we will talk about” meet-up with our Head of Product. We make it a point to sit down every other week to talk about whatever comes to our minds. Last time we ended up talking about how we have become a platform and actually ended up starting a new initiative together. Let’s see if it becomes part of anyone’s “I hate…” or “I love…” list. 😃

More meetings will likely pop up during this week, and hopefully, an interview or two will be added since we are hiring a lot.

I probably won’t get invited to any meetings before noon. At least if I do, I’ll know which of my colleagues are actually reading my posts.

I’m Co-founder and CRO of Airtame. I also wrote about how how we structure our Revenue team between Sales, Marketing & Support:

Don’t Rethink The Organization. Just Add the Right People.
How we went from an engagement-growth-hacker-success-bullshit organisation to a classic marketing, sales & support…medium.com

At Airtame, we are making it easier to use displays wirelessly within organizations. Making meeting rooms wireless and getting dashboards on your office screens with a click. In 2013, we became one of the biggest crowdfunded projects of the time and won “Best of CES”. Now, we are on a journey from an overfunded gadget to a leading company in the B2B space.

Thanks to Jessica Navarro.
